name: title_genres_plot
system_prompt:
You are an assistant tasked with comparing three lists of movies. For each movie, you are given its: title, genres, plot
Your main goal is to assign a diversity score to each list based on the given information.
Use your own judgment to determine what information is relevant when assessing the diversity of the lists. 
You should consider the given title, genres, plot for every movie.

Deliver your descriptions of lists, comparison and choice of the most diverse list in the following JSON format:

{
    "list_A_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list A
    "list_B_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list B
    "list_C_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list C
    "comparison": string,                      # Compare the diversity of the lists.
    "diversity_scores": dict                   # A dictionary assigning a diversity score (0-10) to each list based on its relative diversity. Example: {"A": 5, "B": 2, "C": 10} (where C is the most diverse and B the least).
}

evaluations.prompt:
List A:
TITLE: Big Hero 6 (2014)
GENRES: Animation, Action, Adventure, Comedy, Drama, Family, Fantasy, Sci-Fi
PLOT: A special bond develops between plus-sized inflatable robot Baymax and prodigy Hiro Hamada, who together team up with a group of friends to form a band of high-tech heroes.

TITLE: Others, The (2001)
GENRES: Horror, Mystery, Thriller
PLOT: In 1945, immediately following the end of Second World War, a woman who lives with her two photosensitive children on her darkened old family estate in the Channel Islands becomes convinced that the home is haunted.

TITLE: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
GENRES: Biography, Crime, Drama
PLOT: Barely 21 yet, Frank is a skilled forger who has passed as a doctor, lawyer and pilot. FBI agent Carl becomes obsessed with tracking down the con man, who only revels in the pursuit.

TITLE: Meet the Parents (2000)
GENRES: Comedy, Romance
PLOT: Male nurse Greg Focker meets his girlfriend's parents before proposing, but her suspicious father is every date's worst nightmare.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a broad range of genres and film styles. It includes animation (Big Hero 6), horror (The Others), biographical drama (Catch Me If You Can), romantic comedy (Meet the Parents), drama (Whiplash), documentary (Super Size Me), war drama (The Patriot), and workplace comedy (Office Space).  The plots are also diverse, covering various themes and tones.
response.list_B_description: List B is more focused on action and thriller genres, with several films in the Bourne series and other action/sci-fi movies like Guardians of the Galaxy 2, Edge of Tomorrow, and Iron Man. While it includes some variety with Catch Me If You Can and The Others, the overall thematic and genre consistency is much narrower than List A.
response.list_C_description: List C is nearly identical to List B, sharing most of the same movies and thus exhibiting the same lack of diversity in genre and theme. The inclusion of The Others and Catch Me If You Can does little to offset the dominance of action and thriller films.
response.comparison: List A stands out for its remarkable diversity in genre, tone, and plot. Lists B and C are very similar and primarily feature action, thriller, and sci-fi films, lacking the breadth of List A.  List B and C show very little diversity.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety of genres, including action, drama, horror, sci-fi, thriller, animation, comedy, biography, fantasy, romance, music, and war. response.list_B_description: List B has a good mix of genres, including action, adventure, comedy, sci-fi, crime, thriller, horror, mystery, family, romance, and war.  The plots are diverse, ranging from superhero adventures to psychological thrillers and historical dramas. There is some overlap with List A in terms of movies included.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a more eclectic mix of genres than the other lists, encompassing animation, action, adventure, comedy, drama, family, fantasy, sci-fi, crime, mystery, thriller, documentary, biography, horror, music, romance, sport, western, and musical. The plots are also quite varied, covering superhero stories, mysteries, documentaries, romances, historical dramas, and even a fictional tennis match. This list demonstrates the greatest range of genres and themes.
response.comparison: List C stands out as the most diverse, showcasing a wider array of genres and plot themes compared to Lists A and B. Lists A and B share some common movies and have a more limited range of genres, although they still offer a reasonable level of diversity.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety, including war, drama, comedy, animation, crime, thriller, fantasy, documentary, and musical genres.  However, several films fall into similar subcategories (e.g., multiple comedies and dramas). The plots also share some thematic similarities, such as crime and family themes.
response.list_B_description: List B has a narrower range of genres than List A, focusing mainly on crime, drama, action, and thriller. While there's some variety in subplots (kidnapping, mob revenge, family relationships), the overall thematic consistency limits its diversity.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a more balanced and diverse selection of movies. It includes genres like action, comedy, crime, thriller, sci-fi, fantasy, animation, and biographical elements. The plots are more distinct, covering various themes such as espionage, artificial intelligence, and classic adventure stories. The inclusion of animated films adds to the diversity.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the greatest diversity in terms of genre, plot, and thematic elements. List A shows moderate diversity, while List B is the least diverse, with a concentration on crime, action, and thriller genres.

The trials of Benny Parrish, a young boy diagnosed with bipolar disorder whose troubled soul and vivid imagination create both suffering and joy for him and his complex and loving family. The story of CeeJay Thompson, a black teenager and aspiring football player who has taken refuge in Bombay Beach hoping to avoid the same fate of his cousin who was murdered by a gang of youths in Los Angeles; and that of Red, an ancient survivor, once an oil field worker, living on the fumes of whiskey, cigarettes and an irrepressible love of life. Together these portraits form a triptych of manhood in its various ages and guises, in a gently hypnotic style that questions whether they are a product of their world or if their world is a construct of their own imaginations.â€”Anonymous

response.comparison: List A and List C exhibit comparable genre diversity, but List A offers a wider variety of plot themes and tones, ranging from lighthearted comedies to intense thrillers and thought-provoking dramas. SlingShot is about an indomitable man who just might have enough passion and innovative thinking to create a solution for a crisis affecting billions. Kamen lives in a house with secret passages, a closet full of denim and a helicopter garage. His latest passion: the SlingShot water purification system created to obliterate half of human illness on the planet. Kamen reminisces about improving home dialysis technology and choosing to forgo parenthood while lamenting he has only one lifetime for inventing. response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety of genres and themes. It includes biographical drama (The Imitation Game), fantasy adventure (Lord of the Rings), crime thriller (21), animation (Ice Age), psychological thriller (Black Swan), sci-fi action (Jurassic Park), crime thriller western (Wind River), and romantic comedy (Wedding Crashers).  The plots are diverse, covering war, card counting, prehistoric animals, ballet, dinosaurs, murder investigations, and romantic relationships.
response.list_B_description: List B is similar to List A in terms of genre diversity, but with some differences.  It maintains the biographical drama, fantasy adventure, and crime thriller elements. However, it replaces some of List A's variety with a sports comedy-drama (Bend It Like Beckham), a psychological drama (Fight Club), a crime thriller (Ocean's Eleven), and a historical biographical drama (The Duchess). The plots are still diverse, but with a slightly different focus.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a blend of genres, but with a stronger emphasis on fantasy and drama.  It includes biographical drama (The Imitation Game), fantasy adventure (Lord of the Rings), psychological thriller (Black Swan), fantasy adventure (Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows), romantic sci-fi drama (Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind), animation (Ice Age), fantasy adventure (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban), and crime fantasy drama (The Green Mile). While diverse, it leans more heavily towards certain genres than List A.
response.comparison: List A demonstrates the most balanced and broad range of genres and themes. List B is comparable but shows a slightly narrower focus. List C has a more concentrated selection of genres, particularly in the fantasy and drama categories.  List A's inclusion of a western and romantic comedy sets it apart, offering a greater diversity of storytelling styles and target audiences.

response.list_B_description: List B is less diverse than List A. It shares many of the same movies, maintaining a similar blend of action, fantasy, and thriller genres. response.list_C_description: List C demonstrates the highest diversity. It features a wider range of genres and tones. response.comparison: List C is the most diverse, offering a broader range of genres and film styles compared to Lists A and B. List A shows moderate diversity with a mix of action, fantasy, and thriller elements. List B is the least diverse, largely overlapping with List A and only slightly expanding the genre range.

"In order to go back to being a human again, you must take back all of Kiss-shot's limbs." After receiving advice from Meme Oshino, an expert in the supernatural, Koyomi prepares to go into battle. Awaiting him are three powerful vampire hunters-Dramaturgy, a giant vampire hunter who is a vampire himself. Episode, a half-vampire who wields an enormous cross, and Guillotinecutter, a quiet man who specializes in killing vampires. Will Koyomi be able to take back Kiss-shot's limbs from the vampire hunters? Amidst the soft spring rain, the curtain rises on this fateful blood bath.

TITLE: Circus of Books (2019)
GENRES: Documentary, Biography, History
PLOT: In 1976, Karen and Barry Mason had fallen on hard times and were looking for a way to support their young family when they answered an ad in the Los Angeles Times. Larry Flynt was seeking distributors for Hustler Magazine. What was expected to be a brief sideline led to their becoming fully immersed in the LGBT community as they took over a local store, Circus of Books. A decade later, they had become the biggest distributors of gay porn in the US. The film focuses on the double life they led, trying to maintain the balance of being parents at a time when LGBT culture was not yet accepted. Their many challenges included facing jail time for a federal obscenity prosecution and enabling their store to be a place of refuge at the height of the AIDS crisis. Circus of Books offers a rare glimpse into an untold chapter of queer history, and it is told through the lens of the owners' own daughter, Rachel Mason, an artist, filmmaker and musician.

Though both prequel and sequel to The Omega Code, Megiddo works also as a stand alone story for anyone who missed its predecessor, for, at its emotional core, Megiddo is the Caine and Abel story of the two men enamored with the same woman, raised as brothers, who grew up to find themselves pitted against each other over the fate and souls of the entire world.â€”Anonymous

TITLE: Enemy at the Gates (2001)
GENRES: Action, Drama, War
PLOT: A Russian and a German sniper play a game of cat-and-mouse during the Battle of Stalingrad.

TITLE: Trials of Darryl Hunt, The (2006)
GENRES: Documentary, Crime
PLOT: "The Trials of Darryl Hunt" is a feature documentary about a brutal rape/murder case and a wrongly convicted man, Darryl Hunt, who spent nearly twenty years in prison for a crime he did not commit. Both a social justice story and a personally driven narrative, the film chronicles this capital case from 1984 through 2004. With exclusive footage from two decades, the film frames the judicial and emotional response to a chilling crime - and the implications that reverberate from Hunt's conviction - against a backdrop of class and racial bias in the South and in the American criminal justice system. This documentary is the culmination of ten years of research and filming. In 1993, inspired by claims of injustice and police conspiracy, the filmmakers began to shoot in North Carolina. Working from a mix of formats (16mm and 24P video) the film melds the visceral reality of a murder case with first person accounts and cinematic imagery, illuminating perceptions and memories of events as they unfolded for the people closest to this haunting story. This unique look at one man's loss and redemption challenges the assumption that all Americans have the right to unbiased justice. Hunt's story - while one man's personal journey - reflects systemic issues of national concern: cross-racial eyewitness identification, prosecutorial misconduct, inexperienced defense attorneys assigned to capital cases, racial bias in death penalty cases and errors in police procedure. Barry Scheck from The Innocence Project, who worked on Hunt's case for ten years, and Gary Wells, professor and eyewitness expert, offer concrete examples where errors occurred in Hunt's saga and offer future remedies and effective ideas to prevent future "Darryl Hunts." Hunt himself addresses the need for systemic reforms to prevent wrongful convictions, underscoring the haunting reality that Hunt could have been sentenced to death and we would never have known this story.â€”Annie Sundberg

TITLE: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru (2016)
GENRES: Documentary
PLOT: TONY ROBBINS: I AM NOT YOUR GURU, a feature documentary film about internationally renowned life and business strategist Tony Robbins, is a revelatory cinĂ©ma vĂ©ritĂ© film that goes behind the scenes of his mammoth seminar "Date With Destiny," attended by over 2,500 people in Boca Raton, Florida, each year, to give an insider look at how one man can affect millions. Granted never before seen access to the behind the scenes modus operandi of this enormous event, this film captures both the immense effort of producing this live seminar, as well as the life-changing transformations of the participants in real time. Embedding with Tony Robbins and his team over the course of six days, Academy Award nominated filmmaker Joe Berlinger turns an unflinching eye on Tony Robbins' powerful and uncompromising approach to achieving success, ensuring the attendees leave "Date With Destiny" with new perspective on the forces, thoughts, and feelings that motivate their behavior and help them take control of their lives. Pulling back the curtain on Tony Robbins, a man that traverses the globe and counsels over 200,000 people annually, including world leaders, pundits, entrepreneurs, CEOs, athletes and celebrities, through interviews and unprecedented access, TONY ROBBINS: I AM NOT YOUR GURU is an emotional tour de force that unveils the inner-workings of this mega event, the zealous participants and the man himself.â€”anonymous

But with the fall of the Soviet Union on Christmas Day 1991, Yugoslavia split up. A war broke out between Petrovic's Croatia and Divac's Serbia. Long buried ethnic tensions surfaced. And these two men, once brothers, were now on opposite sides of a deadly civil war. As Petrovic and Divac continued to face each other on the basketball courts of the NBA, no words passed between the two. Then, on the fateful night of June 7, 1993, Drazen Petrovic was killed in an auto accident. "Once Brothers" will tell the gripping tale of these two men, how circumstances beyond their control tore apart their friendship, and whether Divac has ever come to terms with the death of a friend before they had a chance to reconcile.â€”Anonymous

response.list_A_description: List A shows a good degree of diversity, covering various genres including Action, Adventure, Sci-Fi, Documentary, Sport, Drama, Family, Musical, Romance, and Biography.  There's a mix of film types: feature films, documentaries, and animation. The plots also vary significantly, from epic space operas to intimate musical documentaries and personal biographies.
response.list_B_description: List B is less diverse than List A. While it includes some variety in terms of genre (Action, Adventure, Sci-Fi, Comedy, Animation, Family, Fantasy, Romance, Drama), a significant portion of the list is dominated by the Star Wars franchise and action-oriented films. The plots, while different, share a common thread of adventure and conflict.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a moderate level of diversity. It features genres such as Action, Sci-Fi, Thriller, Comedy, Drama, Crime, History, and Fantasy.  The plots are more varied than List B, but less so than List A.  The inclusion of films like 'Requiem for a Dream' and '21' adds thematic diversity, but the presence of 'Star Wars' and 'Shrek' again creates some genre overlap.
response.comparison: List A exhibits the greatest diversity in terms of genre, film type, and plot themes. List B is less diverse due to the heavy presence of similar films, while List C falls somewhere in between, offering a decent variety but with some genre repetition.
